ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A really good understanding of the breadth of social psychology research
General psychology about people and how they affect the environment/how the environment affects them.
Learned about research/studies. As a CS major, I wouldn't say I learned a lot of information that I feel would be useful for the future. Learned some psychology concepts.
Thinking about life and interactions in terms of social psychology studies is interesting.
(Obviously) survey of social psychology, research methods, etc. Application of material and greater connections between theories.
biases in our daily lives, why we think the way we do, and ways we can better ourselves by knowing what goes on in human psychology
Social psychology theories, research methods, how to read research papers, how to apply knowledge of social psychology concepts
I gained a lot of vocabulary and dispelled a lot of myths about why people act the way they do.
I learned a lot of interesting concepts from social psychology and how they were researched
Basic foundations of social psychology, research methods, and a survey of social psyc literature.
I learned so much about how social interaction and principles affect human behavior. It was so helpful to to me as Cognitive Science major.
I gained an understanding of social psychological phenomenon, research that supports or contradicts it, and how it is applied to natural social environments.
Fundamentals of social psyc. A wonderful, accessible grounding on what makes people tick as well as what causes some of the social ills we see today.

Thorough survey of social psychological concepts from attraction and relationships to groups, attributions, biases, and stereotyping. I learned how to apply psychological papers and studies directly to concepts to explain and understand those concepts. I learned how to read psych papers thoroughly and report on them succinctly in written form. I strengthened my writing skills, especially in psychology. I strengthened application of concepts to the real world.
Basic social psychology vocabulary and supporting studies. Able to analyze situations in a psychology context.
Summarizing research, analysis, and lots of cool studies!

This course has been incredibly educational and I've learned so much from Professor Gendron. I've learned a lot about myself through the subject of the course and have been able to reflect on my past experiences through the final project.
A knowledge of lot of science in social psychology.
I learned a bunch of different concepts in social psychology, such was different biases and a lot of research findings.
General knowledge of social psychology.
I learned a lot about how groups work and how people interact socially. I also learned a lot about myself and why I do some of the things that I do.
Many social psychological concepts relevant in our daily lives that I wasn't aware of before, and how research is done to better understand them.
I developed a basic understanding of the field of social psychology.
You get a wonderful overview of social psychology.

I learned all the basic interesting parts of psych. Social Psych is a broad survey course of social psychology, but you do learn a lot of detail about the different units. Id never taken a psych class before and really learned a lot.
Learned about social psychology, the way humans interact, and its current applications.
learned about social psychology concepts and research papers related to those concepts
This course developed a broad overview of social psychology, as well as tied social psychology and relevant concepts into broader social and political phenomena.
Lots about social psychology
A deeper understanding of the connections humans have with each other.
Many psychological concepts that are present in our daily life.
I gained a general overview of what is social psychology and what has been done in the field. I also learned about analyzing scientific literature and thinking critically about them.
Excellent introduction to the various subfields of social psychology. Very broad set of topics.
A general understanding of phenomena in social psychology (attraction, relationships, conflict, groups, etc.). Kind of what you would expect to learn in an Intro Psych class, honestly
i learned a lot about everyday phenomenans and the way that we understand people and groups
A lot about social psychology and real-life applications

I learned a lot of new concepts in social psychology that I can think more deeply about every day and apply them to my life. There are so many biases that humans are prone to that I believe this class helps me attempt to now not fall prey to them.
psychology of interacting with other people; aggression, group behaviors, discrimination/prejudice/stereotypes, different cognitive models, developing appropriate psychological experiments
This course helped me gain insight as the human behavior. It allowed me to see the interconnectedness between social, natural, and political environments and human response.
I gained a breadth of psychology concepts especially in regards to interactions.
How to apply psychology to society!
I gained a better understanding of social psychology and other concepts that will help me with my future classes and career.
I learned about basic social psychological definitions and phenomena and how they impact group life.
Useful psychological concepts that can be applied in the real world
Learned a lot about what makes our social interactions tick!
I learned how to apply concepts to my every day life
I learned the meaning of social psychology and a lot of concepts that apply to our everyday interactions, as well as the purpose behind many studies that tested these concepts.

I have never taken a psychology course before, but this class was a wonderful introduction to the field. I learned how to better empathize with friends, how to understand differences across international societies (which is super helpful for the field I want to work in post-grad), and how to make sense of the emotions and phenomenons (like sadness and bystander effect) that made absolutely no sense even just a semester ago.
I learned a variety of psychological concepts explaining group dynamics and perceptions of the self.

Professor Gendrons course was amazing! She is a wonderful professor and the teaching staff was equally incredible. I learned about fundamental concepts in the field of social psychology as well as how to accurately/effective summarize and analyze empirical psychological studies.

This was a great introduction to social psychology. It really shows how social psych encompasses many concepts and I liked applying to my own life. The response papers provided an excellent way to direct research papers.
I learned how to read and summarize/discuss psychological papers and studies. I learned about many of the studies being done--both currently and in the past--in the field of social psychology.
I was able to better understand how the interactions between individuals affects our behaviour and view of ourselves and others.

I learned about different aspects of social psychology and its applications to real-life events. Some topics included the self in social contexts, affect and emotion, social influence, groups, persuasion, and human conflict. I learned how to write connections to real-world events that applied to topics learned in class and how to synthesize between the different topics.
Overview of many interesting topics in social psychology as well as a good exposure to research literature.
I learned more about the elements of social psychology and how we as humans interact at an individual, societal, and cultural level.
I learned about different concepts, theories, and studies that look into our social behavior. In doing so, I am not able to apply the concepts to the real world.

The insights about the ways in which psychological phenomena affect human behavior and sociality that we learned in this course were really fascinating. As a psychology major, this course was a wonderful one to take! But I am sure non-majors would also greatly enjoy this class.
I learned so much from this course. The textbook was amazing, Professor Gendron was so kind and wonderful. I really liked this class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I like this class a lot, i dont think much could be improved

Strengths: Professor Gendron -- Gave up so many opportunities to understand the material.
Weaknesses: I thought the readings in the book were too long for the info.

I would prefer more structure to the resources - for example on the review guide surveys it would be nice to have a (very) brief summary about the studies listed, because I really can't remember which last names corresponded to which study.

Weaknesses: understanding some of the studies was difficult, and I would have preferred a small summary of some of the more convoluted studies in the notes for when I was reviewing. 
Strengths: notes were excellent, pacing in class was very good, class participation through polls was often enough to be effective, assignments were straightforward
very organized and interesting information

The grading of essays by the TAs was really hit or miss and there were obvious differences in the grading scheme used by each TA. Some were very harsh graders, while others were far more forgiving. There was also little effective feedback given on how to improve our writing, leaving us to just kind of wing it.
There were also way too many papers mentioned in lecture to remember the minute details of for exams and quizzes and I am not surely what there really is to be gained by doing so.

This class is incredible, and I only have positive things to say about it. Professor Gendron is amazing, and her class was engaging and genuinely interesting. I loved how Prof Gendron set up her powerpoints (she clearly put a lot of time into her preparation) and used PollEv. The papers, exams, and project paper had really cool questions that helped me learn psychology on a whole different level by making higher-level connections and application. Even though I attended live lecture and took really careful notes, I still found the weekly quizzes a little bit hard.
The lectures were very engaging and I thought the course was organized well.

One of the weaknesses is that Ed was supposed to be a place that replaced email communication but it felt like Ed posts were gone through on a twice-weekly schedule making it feel like email could have been faster.
The one thing with this class is that lectures feel really long. I don't know if that can be avoided but it was sometimes hard to engage because of the length.

strengths: very organized lecture, clear expectations for students, and a good grading structure
weaknesses: no feedback on the second 2 response papers, could use more real life connections to the course material

Strengths: good content presented, organized lectures, material was clearly explained
Weaknesses: not the most organized when it comes to assignments. Expectations were not always clear.
Strengths: good explanations, compelling material, easy quizzes Weaknesses: none

Strengths: great professor who is accommodating, kind, and thorough. Lectures are succinct yet detailed and digestible. Notes are provided via PowerPoints and delivered nicely, and the format is great for live or asynchronous viewing. Tests are completely doable and do not require extensive memorization. Quizzes are simple and a good way to reinforce content weekly. Workload is manageable and content is extremely interesting.

Weaknesses: survey of many concepts means any one concept is not covered in as much depth as sometimes would be desired.

Strengths: Interesting content, very applicable, and the teaching team genuinely cares about the students. This is the only course where I felt enough effort was put into empathizing with students and actually looking for ways to accommodate those that were struggling. Maria Gendron and her team are fantastic. So grateful for their kindness.

Really well organized and not too difficult, Professor Gendron is super accommodating too. I thought the material was really engaging, too. The papers are pretty manageable and sometimes fun to write (if you're not big on reading research papers, know how to pick ones that are short and easy to summarize). Honestly no big flaws.
I think this course had way too much scientific content for an introductory course.
I loved this class! Everything was super well explained in lecture, the concepts were interesting and applicable to real life, and the essays/projects were actually interesting to complete.

It is a true survey course that covers a lot of topics. The paper assignments are a strength because they provide an opportunity to go more in-depth on some specific topics that each individual students are interested in.
It was a little boring which made it hard to stay engaged.
It was extremely well organized and I really liked the PollEV polls that we did during class, as it helped facilitate engagement.

The structure is very nice, and feedback is always clear. The lectures were super engaging and the content was very interesting. 

No weaknesses!
Studies sometimes not very clearly explained
The strength lies in the teaching and the material.

There were a lot of assignments - response papers, weekly quizzes and readings, two exams and a paper project final was a bit more than I anticipated and I had to spend a lot more time on the screen than I already was.

Dr. Gendron is a major strength of this class. She is the kind of professor that would make any class good  no matter what she teaches. But the class is wonderful too. She really knows how to adapt the class to student needs and build engaging slides that facilitate memory. For example, she always defines key terms clearly on their own slides so students can write them down. When things got tough on campus and in the world, she was flexible with deadlines too.
I thought the poll everywhere questions were really interesting and interactive.
strengths: amazing and interesting content that's useful for daily life
The course was exceptionally well-taught ad the lecture was interactive.
Really interesting
The material was very engaging and relevant to current events

Strengths - Dr. Gendron is very insightful and knowledgeable. Dr. Gendron and the TAs were very open to hear our opinions or suggestions throughout the semester.
Weakness - I know there are a lot of people in the class so I understand in a way, but it took a while to release the grades for some papers and quizzes.

Strengths: This course was taught in a very organized manner, with important terms and relevant literature all marked on the powerpoints. The professor also made sure to include summary slides throughout the lecture which was extremely helpful.
In-person format would be great, which obviously is not at their Professors discretion

Strengths: great content, GREAT, flexible, and understanding prof

no weaknesses

i found this class incredibly engaging and there was a lot of feedback for all the assignments and exams. i loved the format of the exams. I think this class really emphasized learning to learn rather than for a test or for a grade. i felt very supported by professor gendron and the rest of the teaching team

Strengths: very well structured, fun, relevant class

Weaknesses: a lot of material to learn with a lot of assignments. I would have had to credit/d/fail the class if the exams were not open note because I would not have had the time to memorize so much material.

Strengths:
- Prof. Gendron
- broad range of information presented
- compatible with online format
- not too much weight on any one syllabus item

Weaknesses:
-  while there isn't much weight on any particular syllabus item, there are a lot of small components to this class that are somewhat difficult to manage
- labeling of lectures and readings in canvas was not super helpful because they often depended on counting the lectures in the syllabus (if the lectures were already numbered the syllabus or if the readings were labeled by topic rather than lecture number, finding readings would be a lot more intuitive and take less time)
The quizzes were impossible. The tests were good. Quizzes were impossible though.

The strengths of the course are many! The professor is very engaging and passionate about what she teaches. It is taught in a way that is easy to understands and builds upon key concepts. Additionally, the teaching team was receptive to questions and feedback. 
Its weakness lies in the lack of feedback on response papers and exams.
It would be more engaging in person
I think this course provided an interesting overview of concepts, but sometimes quizzes felt very vague.
I enjoyed the material and I think the readings and organization of the course were quite good. The lectures could get a bit unfocused though

The strength of the course was the textbook as it provided a lot of clear information and it was mostly interesting. Also, I appreciated the feedback survey as they were helpful. However, the grading of the course was very disorganized and unclear. All the TAs seemed to grade differently and marked down for petty things. The grading was inconsistent and it felt like the level of work that I put in for each assignment was not worth the effort as the TAs harshly graded and marked down on concepts that I actually explained in the paper. Although I put in hours of studying for the course, the quizzes did not accurately reflect what was taught in the lecture and the book as many questions were confusing and some were not covered in the course material. The lack of feedback for our test answers was also detrimental to our learning.

This course did not seem like a Yale-level course and unfortunately did not facilitate or necessitate much engagement. Topics were covered very generally, with more focus on the definitions of well-known terms (like "discrimination" and "self esteem") and the memorization of the overall conclusions of dozens of papers than on deep analysis of social psychological concepts. At times, I felt like I was in middle school. I wish this course was more like CGSC110/PSYC130, which was an engaging lecture that drew connections between concepts, made students think, looked at real-world applications, and provided a more in-depth study of a smaller number of papers. This is not a critique on the professor herself; she was kind and always open to feedback.
Instructor was very flexible!!
Very engaging material!

The course was very interesting overall because it was easy to see how concepts play out in our everyday lives. The course was also very easy to follow and all materials were provided by the teaching team very effectively to help students succeed.

Strengths: the weekly quizzes reinforced lecture and reading material and the other assignments were interesting ways to apply the concept we learned in class. The TAs were helpful and Professor Gendron is incredibly understanding and passionate about the subject. Weaknesses: none come to mind

This course was very well run the engagement with students is phenomenal. Other courses should model themselves off of Dr. Gendrons course structure as well as her mindfulness and genuine care for students.

Maybe it was the zoom format of the class, but it was hard to feel grounded in the class this semester. It was hard to ever know if I was on track with everyone else or if I was doing the class wrong and with feedback coming late and from different TFs each time, it felt hard to improve.
Strengths: the content is very interesting. Response papers were really helpful in examining research papers. weekly quizzes helped with understanding the content

Strengths: I absolutely loved how this course was organized. The rubrics for each assignment were very clear, and expectations were also clear from the start. The lectures were organized in a very helpful format (discuss a concept, introduce some studies that better explain that concept), and it was honestly one of the clearest lecture formats I've ever seen. I also loved the fact that Dr. Gendron included interactive elements in her Powerpoints. Zoom made focusing on lectures for long periods of time very difficult, but I never had issues focusing in Dr. Gendron's class. Weaknesses: I wish that the guidelines for the exams were made clearer beforehand. I really didn't know what to expect for the first exam. I liked that we reserved class time for review, but I wish that the TAs also held their own review sessions just so that we could hear things explained in a different way.
I think the content was very interesting and Professor Gendron did a great of keeping everyone up to pace.

Strengths of this course are its organization and the material itself. Learning about society is interesting and the way the interactions play out with other people is engaging. The course is also well organized so the material is not overbearing and its split up so that one topic tends to logically flow into the next. A weakness of the course is the Ed discussions. I never managed to use the Ed discussions but last semester I took a different psychology class that used a different program that was more accessible.

Strengths include the organization of the course. A weakness is that feedback was either never given (we couldn't see the correct/incorrect answers of our quizzes), or feedback was vague (response papers, for example).
It was very clear what work we had to complete and by when. The Ed Discussion was also very helpful in getting our questions answered.

Only strengths for this class!!! It was wonderfully organized, and Professor Gendron is an amazing lecturer and a really warm and understanding person. She makes the course extremely engaging and geared towards facilitating student learning. This was definitely my favorite course of the semester.

Strengths: The material was fascinating and presented in a broad overview but very understandable way.

Weaknesses: Too much work with not enough feedback. Assignments included weekly quizzes (out of 10) which we never got to see what we got wrong; 4 essays that were graded weirdly, and, personally, I do not think very well; and 2 exams also which we never got to see what we got wrong and what was the correct answer. The quizzes were okay in making sure we kept up with the course but even if you got a few quizzes with just 1 wrong (9/10) that was already a few 90% which brought down the grade. And god forbid if you got even just one quiz with more than 1 wrong. Also, I do not think I learned anything from taking the quizzes because I could not learn from my mistakes and see what I had gotten wrong. The same goes for the midterm. Additionally, communication on Ed was a little lacking especially in time-sensitive cases from my experience although generally Ed was a good resource.

Professor Gendron was definitely a huge strength for this class. I really liked the lecture content and I though that the textbook reading really enhanced the lecture. The one weakness of this course was that the lectures were a bit long and covered a lot of content per lecture.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i like live lectures were great they kept me really engaged.
Not having class feel mandatory made it easier to miss. Making more live virtual sessions may have been helpful.
Recordings of the lectures are helpful.
Class was pretty good for being virtual.
I really liked the format of the exams and final project paper. Lecture was great and it was nice to be able to watch them over later on.
The lectures included interactive components to make them more engaging. I thought that the lectures were great and formatted well for online learning.
The class was actually very accomodating not only to COVID but other things going on in students lives.
I greatly appreciated the teaching team's flexibility and understanding of the hardship of the pandemic. Live and recorded lectures as well as the organization of the canvas page was very helpful!
Synonymous lectures worked well.
PollEverywhere was great, live and recorded lectures were set up wonderfully.
Just lectures. Overall they were slightly slow but interesting.
Captions on lectures were great! Made the notetaking and studying process so much better. I also really appreciated how accommodating / communicative Professor Gendron was about assignment deadlines.
Recorded lectures and office hours were great! I would only say that I wish the CC option was available for every lecture because it wasn't always.
Great delivery overall.
Everything was recorded, making learning really accessible!
The professor was very flexible in terms of moving deadlines when something came up that affected the while class which was nice.
Since the lectures were live virtual lectures, I think the PollEV polls were a very useful practice that was successfully geared toward helping the class during the pandemic.
Dr. Gendron always made it easy for us, being aware that this was a hard semester, giving us more time for assignments. I think the course practices were great.
would have been really helpful to get our weekly quizzes back so we could learn and improve from them

Dr. Gendron knows how to engage with a class over Zoom. Idk what shes doing differently than my other professors, but when students have questions, she sees it right away. Her online quizzes are very good.

I appreciated the use of interactive tools such as polls, as well as the use of video and other media to supplement lecture content. I also liked the EdStem board, that was very helpful. My main difficulty with the course was not being able to attend many office hours. As someone outside of the Eastern Time zone, not all office hours were particularly accessible.
Accommodated well for covid circumstances
I thought the course was geared well for COVID-19

I really loved the option for a creative final project but thought having an exam so near the end of the term and a final project was a little overwhelming. But, overall, I can't complain because I really appreciated the grade breakdown for this class and how all four areas (exams, quizzes, responses, and final project) were all weighted equally.
Live zoom class format worked well for this class.
The use of closed captions and allowing us to take this course asynchronously was extremely helpful
Weekly quizzes, recorded lectures were great
The Ed Discussion center was very helpful for having a community of people with whom to communicate and ask questions, given that we could not ask them in person.

Strengths:
- recorded lectures
-  no additional Zoom sessions (i.e. discussion sections)
- Poll Everywhere worked well for the most part

Weaknesses: none at the moment, it was a good online format
This class was well geared towards virtual learning. The lectures were recorded, allowing for students to go back to course materials and there were plenty of mediums to ask questions.
It would be more engaging in person
I think the online virtual lectures were interesting, but sometimes it was difficult to stay engaged on Zoom. The polls especially helped.
Generally the course did a great job of making support available.

The grading should be greatly improved as it was highly inconsistent and unclear. Additionally, not having the TA comments available for our graded papers was a major weakness that affected future papers. The teaching team should be aware of the varying schedules of the students and not pressure us to attend office hours just to view our paper feedback.
minimal engagement during lecture made it hard to focus, poll everywhere was helpful
N/A was very engaging.
They were helpful and understanding with deadlines
I liked how the course was live to be more engaging, but also recorded for convenience.

The use of PollEverywhere was a quick and fun way to engage with the course material, despite the virtual nature of our lectures. The fact that we had a class-wide Ed discussion board was also helpful in efficiently answering questions throughout the semester.
An ED discussion was set up to answer our questions in real time. Active changes were made to the syllabus in the interest of student mental health.
Ed discussion was an AMAZING addition
I thought having live lecture was great. I really liked the use of polleverywhere in answering some interesting questions

I loved that most of the readings were online. I also loved that Dr. Gendron's Powerpoints were super interactive; online school made focusing on long lectures very difficult for me, but the interactive elements kept me engaged. The lecture format was also consistent every week, which provided me with a nice routine for this class. Online classes are already uncertain enough, but some of my other classes simply didn't establish a routine that would have helped students stay engaged. Dr. Gendron's classroom kept me engaged, and her expectations were always clear.
Very flexible, recorded lectures have been helpful

The PollEv surveys during the lectures were really nice in keeping engagement high and it helped me stay focused on the lecture. What could be improved is the Ed system to ask questions as I remember there being a different program that served a similar function and was better for me to ask questions in. Accessibility to the readings and lecture slides on Canvas was very helpful for review.
The teaching staff was immensely flexible and this made all the difference in turning this class into the most enjoyable COVID-19 adjusted course that I have taken all year.
Zoom lectures ran very smoothly, however, an area of improvement could be leaving more time for questions.
The lectures were really well organized.

This class was one of the only classes that really took into account COVID issues. The professor and the TAs were particularly aware of the worldly goings-on and often pushed back a deadline a few days to allow people to understand what was going on and to take a day for themselves. As long as people were communicative with them, they were very understanding and would work with you.
I thought that having the interactive poles was a great COVID addition to the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it if you are a freshman, or sophomore interested in psych or a junior who hasnt taken any other psych courses. As a psych major it was just a bit redundant with my other classes who focus on the same topics in greater detail so i personally found it a bit dull, but if i have taken it as a freshman or sophomore i would have been much more engaged
Yes-- learning is helpful in real life and it is taught well.
If you want an easy class, sure.
Yes, I got a social science credit and feel that I learned a good amount and changed some of the ways I think about interactions and behavior.
yes

It's a bit more work than I'd like from a gut class but the material is easy enough that it was definitely manageable as a 5th class. It was my first psych class at Yale so I'd recommend it for anybody who wants to get their toes wet into the field of psychology

If you're looking for a psyc major requirement, this is a decent course for the core social science. However, there might be better options (like clinical psyc or psyc 140) so check those out and see if you might be more interested in them.
100% YES!! Professor Gendron is incredible, and the course material is fascinating. Those two things combined make this class superb.

Yes; it goes through all the basic concepts in psychology and helps you get a better grasp on why we might think a certain way. I think it's important for everyone to have a little bit of understanding about psychology of the human mind so we can be better people.
Yes, I would recommend this course to all students who are interested in psychology. The topics are diverse and interesting and the pace/format of the class is very manageable.
Yes, especially if you are considering taking an extra credit this course feels like half a credit course.
I would recommend it as an interesting lecture to take but would warn them that the reading responses are hard to do well on
Professor Gendron was great, if you have the opportunity to take this class with her, I highly recommend it.
Definitely, I would actually recommend this course to anyone who wants to know more about how people behave in certain situations.
It's a fantastic course that dips into the concepts of social psychology. I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the subject.
100 percent! Professor Gendron is a sweetheart. Great as a fifth class.

Yes. It is a great way to survey a subsection of the very broad discipline of psychology. It'll help you learn if psych is interesting for you and if you like working with research, or if you prefer the theory/concepts. Professor is great and the workload and assessments are extremely fair, if not generous, and manageable.
Yes, everyone should take this course. Everyone should have exposure to social psychology.

Yes, I really loved social psych and would recommend it to anyone interested in social interaction / societal behavior at all. Also great for people trying to better understand their own social anxiety lol. The workload is very manageable and Professor Gendron is wonderful.
Yes! I think it's really informative and Professor Gendron was always so attentive and aware of varying circumstances for students and made accommodations as needed.
Yes, it is a great introduction to social psychology.
Yes!!!! It's not a hard class, but especially if you like psychology classes, this one will be perfect.
I would definitely recommend this class if you have no experience in social psychology - for someone who is already fairly familiar with social psychology, it may not be the best use of time.
Yes.
Probably not, I might tell them to take a different psychology class.
No
Yes  great psychology course for premed!
Yes, I would. It gave me a lot of opportunity to self-reflect and understand why I am the way I am in a lot of aspects, so I would encourage others to take this course and do the same.
Definitely! Interesting content, engaging classes, caring professor and relatively low workload. Perfect class if interested in psych!
Absolutely, it is so important in content to learn about social psych
If you need a conceptually-easy psych course, this one does the trick.
I highly recommend! Its so relevant to real life.
Yes, because you gain a basic understanding of social psychology and learn about a lot of interesting studies.

Definitely! One of my favorite classes at Yale so far. It was fun, interesting, engaging, and not too hard. Also Dr. Gendron is a gem of a professor. Would totally recommend. Also, you do NOT need intro psych or AP Psych for this class. This is very much an intro psych class.
Yes
I LOVED THIS COURSE. not a psych major but loved every bit of it. you learn about things that are actually useful for life, it's so interesting and helps you understand behavior better
Yeah, it's very low workload, the professor and TFs are all super nice, and the material is reasonably interesting.
I would certainly recommend this course as an introduction to Social Psychology.
Yes it's really good an super interested
Yes, the material was engaging and fun and professor gendron is a great lecturer!
Great class for those interested in social psych but dont have much prior psychology  knowledge. For those that do, it might not be as stimulating.

Definitely! It gives a lot of useful and relevant insight on information that can be regularly applied outside of the classroom which I found refreshing. Also, it was a low stakes environment to explore these concepts and allow yourself to apply them to your own life.
Yes! I learned so much and especially during this covid-19 time, studying social psychology was very helpful.
Yes, this is a great introductory course, especially for those without background in psychology. The professor is open to questions and lectures in a clear and thorough manner.
Yes, very intellectually enriching
Yes, if you are interested in psychology at all.

absolutely, i think this class is a really useful class if you are interested in psychology or education or just understanding social processes. I think there are a lot of ways to make this class personal and you can get exactly what you want out of it
Yes!
Yes! Amazing course if you are remotely interested in psychology or social psych
Of course!
Yes! A very relevant class to anyone, whether they are a psych major or whether this is their first psych class. All the content concerns our daily lives.

I would recommend this course to other students; it's a good survey course for those interested in social psychology or psychology more generally who would like to learn a little about a lot. But, given there are a fair number of little assignments to remember, I would probably only recommend to students who have a specific interest in the field rather than as just a fun, convenient course to take for fun/to shake things up.
Yes! The professor is great and you learn cool concepts that are practical in the real world.
I would recommend this course to other students. It is taught very well and covers fascinating topics.
Yes, I would because the social psychology concepts were very interesting.
Yes I would. Its a great course even if you havent engaged with psychology in an educational setting in the past.

It depends. I would recommend the course because the content was very intriguing and highly useful, but the inconsistent grading is unfair for the students and could harm their grades and future prospects.
Yes!
If you need it as a requirement, genuinely want to learn about very basic social psychology, or are looking for a total gut (unfortunately).
Yes
Yes! Super interesting and I learned a lot.
Yes!
Yeah

This course is sometimes interesting and the topics are definitely interesting, but the lecture can often be long winded, and often needed to be watched sped up to maintain interest. But I would recommend this, especially if you're a psychology (or something related like cog-sci) major, or if you're looking for a psych class that's somewhat interesting without too much work.
Yes, I would recommend this course both to Psych majors to fulfill a requirement and also to any non-psych majors who are looking for an interesting class to take.
Yes! Lovely class for survey course on social psychology and Professor Gendron is a sweetheart :)

Yes! This class is a wonderful introduction to social psychology. You will leave with a better understanding of not only how and why greater society thinks/acts in certain ways, but also with a more comprehensive understanding of how you as an individual function psychologically. The course workload is not too heavy and the material is as interesting as it is applicable to the (many) issues happening around the world today.

Yes! The material is very interesting and applicable to everyday life. The assignments are also pretty fun and a good way to gauge understanding. All the TAs and Professor Gendron are incredibly invested and understanding. Would highly recommend!
Yes! Professor Gendron is amazing and social psychology is extremely relevant no matter your major
Nope, the professor and TAs dont rlly care about grading

Absolutely! Maria Gendron is incredibly kind, patient, and understanding. The material itself isn't too challenging. If you pay attention during lectures, you'll definitely do well in class. In addition, I found the material incredibly fascinating and it was interesting being able to relate the content to my own personal life.
I would recommend this course to everyone. All the concepts are very relevant and applicable to life.

Absolutely! If you aren't a fan of how broad the intro to psych class is, this class really hones in on the field of social psych, which is broad enough to include many subjects but narrower than tackling the whole field of psychology in one semester. This class took my favorite parts of the intro to psych class and expanded on them.

I would recommend this course to other students if they feel that they are interested in psychology and particularly if they would like to learn more about how interactions between people affect our behavior. They say if is recommended to take this class with another intro pscyhology class but it was my first psychology class and all the concepts were explained as if they were new so I never felt like I was behind others.

I would recommend this course to another student. I think the material is interesting to most people and the amount of different topics in society covered allow for a broad introduction to the field of social psychology. The workload is not as bad as some other classes and the amount of resources available if students need help is nice along with the professor and TAs being readily available to help.
If you are interested in psychology and how individuals understand the world around them, take this course! The teaching staff is great and you will think a ton about what you learn.

I would recommend this course to anyone even remotely interested in psychology. Most of the topics we learn about in this course is applicable to your daily life, and the content is super interesting to think about.

Dr. Gendron taught the course very well! I was able to learn about different theories and studies which I would relate to the real world. The class is very engaging in making you apply and consider the studies of our social behavior.

Absolutely!!! Its an amazing class, and Professor Gendron is a wonderful lecturer and a really warm and understanding person. I had a lot of fun in this class, and all of the concepts I learned were absolutely fascinating.
Yes, if only because Maria Gendron is a great person and professor as well as the actual material of the class is great.
Yes! I thought is was super interesting.

Eh? The content is very interesting, especially since the professor connects concepts to current issues and research. The professor is very kind and thoughtful (often pushing back or allowing more time for assignments after some of the tragedies that occurred this semester). However, the professor is not the most engaging -- she speaks very slow and very monotone -- so it's easy to zoom out, especially when this course will be in-person with no x2 play option. There are weekly quizzes and quite a lot of papers, but assignments are mostly short and graded easily. Not a total gut, but interesting content (particularly if you already like psych or understanding social interactions) with a lighter course load in terms of grading, but not in the number of assignments.
